title: DataViz Makeover 2
contents:
Introduction



For this makeover, the task at hand is to critique a bubble chart which represents the total trade happening between Singapore and 10 of its trading partners between 2011-2020


The steps taken is to first identify what was done wrong in the given visualization, sketch the plan on how to improve it, and then create the improvement using Tableau Desktop.


Critique of Visualization



For this makeover, the original visualization can be seen below.




Figure 1: original visualization




The bubble chart above shows a relationship of 3 variables between Singapore and some of its trading partners which are the total import shown in the y-axis, the total export shown in the x-axis, and the total merchandise trade represented by the size of each bubble. In addition, the placement of the center of each bubble shows whether the relationship between Singapore and that partner is if Singapore is a net importer, net exporter or is balanced with that specific partner.


Looking initially at the graph, some critiques can be given based on its clarity and aesthetic which will be discussed further in this section.


Clarity


Missing graph title makes readers hard to instantly understand what the bubble chart shows.
No specific explanation as to what the label next to each bubble is, further contemplation with relation to the size of bubble mentioned in a small note results in the conclusion that the label shows the total trade (export + import).
No clarification as to by how much Singapore has a surplus (if net exporter) or deficit (if net importer) with its trading partners.

Aesthetic


Too many partners clumped together makes it hard to see the exact placement of bubbles.
Using colour code to label trade partners makes it unintuitive
Bubbles covered by annotations of a partner next to it makes it difficult to see if that bubble is in a net importer or net exporter region.
Blue and green background to show a trade surplus or deficit is not ideal since both colors generally represent a positive tone.

Makeover Proposal Sketch


Based on the issues identified in the previous section, an improved visualization can be developed that addresses the listed problems. A sketch of the graph model can be seen in the figure below.




Figure 2: sketch of improvement




Clarity


Added title to clearly convey what the chart is aiming to inform.
Annotations turned into tooltips to not take up space when information not needed.
Trade balance added as info to tooltip.


Aesthetics


Size of bubble and axes adjusted to avoid too much parts clumped together
Bubble uses flags of each partner instead for more instantaneous recognizition by readers.
annotations changed to tooltips
Region color changed to orange (for net import) and green (for net export) for a more intuitive color code of having a negative or positive trade balance.

Proposed Visualization




Figure 3: sketch of improvement




Above is a static image of the visualization improvement. An interactive version can be seen in Tableau Public Here.


Steps Documentation


Data Preparation

Before any visualizations can be made, some data preparations must first be conducted using Tableau Desktop. The steps taken include:

Import the dataset to Tableau. Click on the “Microsoft excel” option in the connect data pane.



Figure 4: import excel file.



Select the dataset file.



Figure 5: import excel file.



Drag “New Union” to the data prep sheet and select the T1 and T2 sheets.



Figure 6: union of the 2 worksheets



On the left side of the screen, tick the “Data Interpreter” to skip the rows containing the title of the sheet.



Figure 7: enable ‘Data Interpreter’



In the top right side, click on the “filters”, then “Add..”, then “variables” and select the 10 trading partners that will be visualized.



Figure 8: filter the used trade partners



On the fields that are not the years used (ie. not between 2011-2020), highlight all of them and right click then click hide.



Figure 9: hide months outside of used range



Highlight all columns except for “Variables”, “Sheet” and “Table Name” fields, then right click one of the highlighted column and click on “Pivot”.



Figure 10: pivot the month fields



The “Import” and “Export” fields are still combined and must first be separated. First create the “Import” Field using this calculation.



Figure 11: import calculation



The “Export” field uses a similar calculation.



Figure 12: export calculation



In the “Variables” field, click on “create calculated field” with the shown formula to remove the “(Thousands Dollar)” or “(Million Dollar)” part of the name.



Figure 13: clean the trade partner name



Create a “Merchandise Trade” field by adding “Import” and “Export”.



Figure 14: create merchandise trade field




Background Creation


For this graph, the background will be divided into 2 regions, net importer and net exporter. Therefore, a background with such a color scheme will be first created to be loaded into the visualization as a background image. The steps are listed as follow.

Create an excel file with the fields “position”, “import” , “export” and “stat”. Position refers to points of angle in which this case the background will be divided into 2 triangles, hence 3 positions for each status. The import and export would be the maximum and minimum value in each corresponding axes.



Figure 15: created excel file



Import the file into Tableau.



Figure 16: file selected to import



Drag the fields into the appropriate axes.



Figure 17: fields dragged to row and column



Drag the “stat” field into the “color” mark.



Figure 18: stat field added to mark



In the “Analysis” pane, un-tick the “Aggregate Measures” option.



Figure 19: disable the ‘Aggregate Measures’



Change the mark type from “Automatic” to “Polygon” and drag the “Stat” field into “Path”.



Figure 20: background created



Export the chart as a .png extension with only “view” ticked.



Figure 21: file export settings




Flag Icons Creation


On top of backgrounds, the bubble of each trading partner will also feature its flag. Therefore, custom shapes must also be created using Microsoft word and images of the flags found online. The steps are done as follow.

In Microsoft Word, create a circle shape



Figure 22: circle shape



Right click the object then select “Fill” and then click on “Picture”



Figure 23: fill circle with picture



Select the image file



Figure 24: image file selected



Right click on the object select “Format Shape” and set the placement and sharpness until the image fits the circle and looks good.



Figure 25: fixed image proportions



Right click the object and select “Save as Picture”



Figure 26: save object as image



Choose the directory My Documents > My Tableau Repository > Shapes then create a new folder and save the image on that new folder



Figure 27: file save path



Repeat the steps for all flags needed



Figure 28: flag icons for all partners




Chart Creation


With the data fully cleaned and connected as well as the background region and flag icons created. The chart can then be created with the following steps.


Drag the “Export” and “Import” fields to the “Columns” and “Rows” section, respectively.



Figure 29: placement of fields



Drag the “Trade Partner” field to the “Shape” mark.



Figure 30: trade partners dragged to shape mark



Left click on shape, select the custom-made shape palette and assign each flag to its corresponding partner



Figure 31: assignment of flags



Drag the “Merchandise Trade” field to the size mark and adjust the slider to a proper level.



Figure 32: adjustment of size



To add the background image, first go to Map > Background Images > Union.



Figure 33: add background image path



In the “add image” section, browse for the exported background and set the max value in the x-axis and y-axis to 750B.



Figure 34: add background image



On the x and y axes, set the limit to 700B.



Figure 35: set axis range



Add Area Annotations to mark the regions for “Net Importer” and “Net Exporter”



Figure 36: region annotations added



In the “Trade Partner” field, select create > group



Figure 37: create new group



Create groups by CTRL click the partners then press group and name the group based on the regions. Also tick the “Include Other” box to group USA and EU.



Figure 38: group partners by region



Rename the group to “Region” then drag the group and the “Trade Partner” field to filters.



Figure 39: group renamed and added to filters



In the “Export” field, right click and select create calculated field with the following formula



Figure 40: trade balance calculation



Drag the newly created field to “Tooltip” mark



Figure 41: trade balance added to tooltip



Format the placement of the tooltips to create an even lining with each other.



Figure 42: format placement of tooltips



Rename the title of the chart



Figure 43: title properly renamed



Add another annotation for the source of data



Figure 44: source added




Generated Insights

From the chart created, useful information about Singapore’s trade can be inferred. Some of the more interesting findings are listed below.
In general, Singapore has net import trade relationships with developed countries (Japan, USA, EU, Korea) while having net export trade relationships with developing countries (Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand).
In relation to the “Gravity Model of Trade”, which states an entity will trade more in relative to a partner’s size and proximity. Singapore’s biggest trade partners are geographically farther (e.g., EU, USA, China) while it trades less with nearer countries (i.e., Indonesia and Thailand), making it seem that Singapore leans more to the economic size of a partner than the proximity. Malaysia, which is Singapore’s nearest neighbor country is the only exception.
Singapore’s imports primarily include machinery and equipment, mineral fuels, chemicals, food and consumer goods ASEAN Briefing. This would explain why regions abundant in natural resources (e.g., USA, Malaysia, China, EU) would have higher import trades happening, albeit not necessarily making Singapore a net importer to them, while regions with little natural resources such as Thailand and Hong Kong have a much lower import value compared to how much Singapore exports to them.

title: DataViz Makeover 1
description: Given a graph, this article will cover the critiques concerning said graphs, plans on how to improve visualization, and steps to create the sketched improvement using Tableau Desktop.
contents:
Critique of Visualization



For this makeover, the original visualization can be seen below.



Clarity


The title of the visualization does not clearly convey what kind of information it is trying to give. While it is true the graph represents merchandise trade, it does not state which country is trading with those six countries. Furthermore, no explanation on what currency is used as its unit leaves the numbers meaningless to the readers.
In addition, the y-axes are in the millions while looking at the data the values are in billions. Thereby revealing that the visualization fails to mention that the values are divided by 1 thousand anywhere in the title.
The x-axis says “month of period” which would imply the dataset is a monthly time series. However, the values used in that axis is instead the years with no specific starting and ending months.
Low data ink ratio from the area chart makes it hard for readers to infer what the chart is trying to inform.
5 of the 6 countries visualized has the same range of export and import values (millions). However, the ticks of the y-axes are not in the same height which may lead to readers falsely assuming that export and import at a certain time are equal while the reality is far from it. In addition, the difference in height between the countries would make it hard for readers to see which countries are trading more than the others (e.g. the graph would imply that Japan and China are equal trading partners to Singapore based on the graph height. However, looking at the numbers the 2 countries have a difference of over 4 billion SGD in monthly merchandise trading).
No source of data gives the graph less credibility to the readers.
No annotations to further communicate what the graph is trying to explain to the readers.

Aesthetics


Choice of words in graph title using “merchandise trade” makes it harder for the average reader to understand.
The choice to fill the graph color all the way down to the x-axis makes it hard for readers to see the values especially when the Import graph is higher than the Export graph.
Using dual axis on the same magnitude and unit makes it redundant.
No tick marks on the x-axis despite being a continuous data.
Title of the y-axes are placed vertically, making It hard for viewers to read.
Placement of legend at the far right makes readers hard to continually identify which color represent each dataset.

Makeover Proposal Sketch


Based on the issues identified in the previous section, an improved visualization can be developed that addresses the listed problems. A sketch of the graph model can be seen in the figure below.



Clarity


The title has been changed to reflect the data presented. The graph shows the trades happening between Singapore and its top 6 trading countries. In addition, the unit of numbers are also added to give clarity on what currency is used for the data.
The y-axis range has been changed to Billions as is the real dataset is to eliminate confusion of the true value of trades happening.
Tick marks in x-axis changed from yearly to monthly.
High data ink ratio from eliminating the area makes it easy for readers to infer the values.
Label height for both y-axes have been standardized to 0-8 billion SGD. This is done such that not only the export and import values of one graph can be more easily distinguished, but the values from one country graph to another can also be immediately compared without consulting the labels for each country graph.
The source of data which is Singapore government’s Department of Statistics is added to give credibility to the visualization.
Annotations are added to any points of interest found to give a deeper understanding to the readers.
Order of appearance sorted based on magnitude for ease of comparison


Aesthetics


“Merchandise trade” has been changed to “Export and Import of Goods”. While “Merchandise Trade” is the correct terminology used by WTO, “Export and Import of Goods” is also a correct term which has the same meaning and is also more widely understood by the average readers.
The line graph is not filled to the bottom to make the graphs easier to read.
Only 1 axis is used considering both exports and imports are in the billions SGD magnitude and unit to eliminate redundancy.
Tick marks added to the x-axis in accordance with added labels discussed in the Clarity sub-section.
Titles of the y-axes are rotated to horizontal for ease of reading.
The legends are incorporated into the dashboard title to give readers a faster way to reference the colors while also adding aesthetic features to the title.

Proposed Visualization


The proposed visualization improvement can be seen in Tableau Public Here.


Steps Documentation


Data Preparation


Before any visualizations can be made, some data preparations must first be conducted using Tableau Desktop. The steps taken include:


Import the dataset to Tableau. Click on the “Microsoft excel” option in the connect data pane.

Select the dataset file.

Drag the T1 sheet to the “drag tables here” part of the screen.

On the left side of the screen, tick the “data interpreter” to skip the rows containing the title of the sheet.

In the top right side, click on the “filters”, then “Add..”, then “variables” and select the 6 countries that will be visualized.

On the fields that are not the years used, highlight all of them and right click then click hide.

Highlight all columns except for “Variables”, right click one of the highlighted column and click on pivot.

Rename the pivoted fields.

Change the type of “Month” field from “string” to “date”.

In the Import field, click “Create Calculated Field” and set code to multiply by 1000 to eliminate (in thousands) clarifier

In the “Variables” field, click on “create calculated field” with the shown formula to remove the “(Thousands Dollar)” part of the country.

In the “worksheet” window, select “Data” menu, then “New Data Source” select the dataset and repeat the steps for the T2 sheet.

Go to “Data” menu, then click on “Edit Blend Relationships” to check if both data sources have been matched in the “Month” and “Variables” fields and then click “OK”.

Make sure the data is linked in “Country” and “Month”, the data is linked if the icon is red



Graph Creation


With the data fully cleaned and connected, the graphs can then be created with the following steps.


Drag “Country” and “Month” fields to columns pane and “Export” and “Import” to rows pane. Then on the right axis, right click and choose “Synchronize Axis” and deselect “Show Header”. Then set month format to “Month/Year” and fit the graph by width.

Edit Axis” the left axis and delete the title

In the “Rows” section, double click and type “Merchandise Trade (S$)”

Right click on the top part of “Merchandise Trade (S$)” and “Country/Month” and click “Hide Field Labels for Rows” and “Hide Field Labels for Columns”, respectively.

Dashboard Creation

With the visualization created, the dashboard can be built by clicking the “New Dashboard” button.
In a new dashboard, drag text object to the dashboard and type the title

Drag another text object below the title to provide space for commentary later

Drag the worksheet below the commentary box and adjust the proportion between the 3 objects

When creating annotations, right click the box and select “Format”, change the shading to a low percentage to allow y-axis label marks to be seen and select a line color that is visible

Write annotations and comment, as well as drag the graphs around to sort by magnitude

Drag text object at bottom of dashboard and add source of data


Generated Insights


A sharp jump in exports from February 2020 to April 2020 for 3 of the 6 countries (Mainland China, United States, and Hong Kong) as well as a slight rise for another 2 (Japan and Taiwan) may be in most parts due to a high influx of demand for pharmaceuticals and medical supplies caused by Covid-19. StraitsTimes
In January – April 2020, Malaysia experiences a sharp decline in export and import with Singapore due to shutdown of its many key economic sectors due to the pandemic, creating the worst slump in trade for the constitutional monarchy since the 2008 financial crisis. TheEdgeMarkets , Malaysia Department of Statistics
With china starting to recover by late 2020, August 2020 saw the largest export to china mostly in non-oil products due to rising demands, a 104% increase from January 2020. BloombergQuint
